results.title: Her Film on Sex Assault Depicts Her Own and Fuels a #MeToo Moment
results.abstract: Danijela Stajnfeld included her account of being assaulted in a film that has led to contentious debate in Serbia and prompted other women to come forward to say they were sexually abused.

results.title: A Tiny Icelandic Town Campaigns for the Oscars
results.abstract: First Husavik was the setting for the Netflix film “Eurovision Song Contest: The Story of Fire Saga.” Now, a song named after the town is up for an Oscar.

results.title: Larry McMurtry, Novelist of the American West, Dies at 84
results.abstract: In “Lonesome Dove,” “The Last Picture Show” and dozens more novels and screenplays, he offered unromantic depictions of a long mythologized region.

multimedia.caption: The author Larry McMurtry in 1978 at home. In a career that spanned more than five decades, he wrote more than 60 novels and screenplays.
multimedia.copyright: Diana Walker/The LIFE Images Collection via Getty Images

results.title: Bertrand Tavernier, 79, French Director With Wide Appeal, Dies
results.abstract: He was a regular on the world’s film festival circuit with movies like “Death Watch,” a science-fiction thriller, and “’Round Midnight,” about a jazz musician.

multimedia.caption: The director Bertrand Tavernier at the Rome Film Festival in 2019. He won a best director award at Cannes for “A Sunday in the Country.”

results.title: Janet Jackson and Kermit the Frog Added to National Recording Registry
results.abstract: The Library of Congress has designated 25 recordings, from modern pop hits to one of the earliest recordings of an American voice, as “audio treasures worthy of preservation for all time.”

multimedia.caption: “The Rainbow Connection,” Kermit the Frog’s banjo-strumming song from “The Muppet Movie” (1979), is among the new entries.

results.title: George Segal, Veteran of Drama and TV Comedy, Is Dead at 87
results.abstract: He is best remembered for his Oscar-nominated dramatic role in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and was later a familiar comic actor.

multimedia.caption: George Segal in 1997. In a long and varied career, he won acclaim opposite Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton in “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” and later appeared in TV comedies like “Just Shoot Me!”

results.title: Can You Love a Stand-Up Special About Loathing?
results.abstract: James Acaster’s “Cold Lasagne Hate Myself 1999” is an outstanding show about the worst year in his life, a confessional set from a performer who didn’t like to talk about his personal life.
